photos.people: Carroll Culver, Bruce Culver, Ken Culver
photos.description: Carroll Culver with Ken and little brother Bruce in the back yard at Grandma Rothehoefer's house at Montlake in Seattle.  (Ken)

The year of the big snow.  We were snowed and frozen in for several weeks.  Roads impassable, power out much of the time, and all water pipes frozen.  My dad carried water from Alderbrook Creek.  The Doe Bay school bus could not run, but school went on for the western half of the Island.  My Mom put me on the Osage at Doe Bay and I got off at Eastsound where I stayed for about a week with Perry Kimple , one of my classmates.  The Kimples owned the local telephone company and Mrs. Kimple was the operator who sat in a little bay window on the street side of the house and plugged callers into various little round holes to connect with people outside their immediate party line.  I was fascinated to watch as she sat there for hours with a little headset and speaker.  She could leave her station and still hear if someone rang for the operator (1 long crank).  She would step out of the kitchen and  connect them.  The system was shut down at night, however in an emergency you could call and wake her up.  Clara Abrahamson of Doe Bay also worked as an operator.  (Ken)

photos.location: Grandma Nell Rothenhoefer's home in Montlake, Seattle
photos.people: Grandma Nell Rothenhoefer in the backyard at her home in Montlake, Seattle. Ken, Bruce, Carolyn, and Michael Rothenhoefer.
photos.description: The striped canvas was a large lawn swing which I confess took quite a beating, and was tipped over backwards many times from overzealous swinging.  Much to the chagrin of Grandma. (Ken)

Ken and Bruce with the families second "woody" station wagon, pictured in front of the little house in Marysville, WA where we lived for one year while Carroll and Jean were separated.  Our first "woody" was a 1941 Ford station wagon with real wood sides and a 3 speed column shift.  This was a Chevy and had fake wood that faded quickly and was a gutless automatic.  Jean taught school in Marysville.  A strange transitional year, at least in my life.  (Ken)

Ken with a couple of nice Silvers.  If I recall this was my birthday, when I always got the day off - spared from the chores of the resort.  Usually I chose to take one of the rental boats and go fishing on the North Shore by myself.   Mid to late August was when the Silvers would show up in droves, usually working their way down the North Shore towards Pt. Lawrence.  I would cut herring strips with a  4 oz crescent sinker and troll close to the surface.  You could often see the fish come flashing across the water like a torpedo and hit that bait - Boom!  You had a fight on your hands - Silvers were high energy, often making long surface runs and tail walking in an attempt to toss the hooks.  Little Jack salmon were so common at that time that I often tied a Pearl Wobbler or 4 1/2 McMahon spoon onto a short hand line and dragged it about 15 feet behind the boat with no weight.  That would keep the jacks from stealing your fresh cut herring strip.   (Ken)

photos.location: Willis family home - Obstruction Pass area,  Orcas Island.
photos.people: Left to right:  Ken, Bruce Congdon, Virgil Carlson, John Willis, Roger Congdon, Bruce Brandt, Bruce Culver.
photos.description: A celebration of John Willis's birthday.  All of us lived to the East of Olga - in those years the Doe Bay school bus picked you up right after school so there was no chance to interact after school like some of the Eastsound kids who walked to school did.  So our circle of friends was pretty local back then.

Front page of "The Journal of the San Juan Islands", December 1982. Caption: "Carroll Culver, a longtime resident of Doe Bay, paraded in the Olga Day celebrations last May along with a model of the good old Vashon that he made for his kids 30 years ago."

photos.people: Bruce Culver (Age 5.5 Months), Great Grandma Burt
photos.description: Great grandma Burt at the back door of the Rothenhoefer home in Seattle.  This was Nell Rothenhoefer's mother.  Stern German who I never saw smile.   (Ken)
Photo of Carroll Culver at his graduation from Washington State University.

The Legendary Cap Bell and Bellingham fisherman Earl Jewel sitting in front of the smoke house.  Cap Bell was a local character, and I do mean character, that often hung around the Lodge and lived at one point or another in Cabin 4.  He caught herring to sell for bait, and stored them in a floating live box anchored in the bay.  Cap often used a herring rake to impale herring, and was not above using a half stick of dynamite if there was a large herring ball out in front.  He would light a short fuse, and quickly drop it over the side.  A large muffled thud would be heard, and then hundreds of stunned herring would come to the surface for easy netting.  That process was outlawed and may have even been illegal at the time.  When we tore down Cabin 4 we found a package wrapped in heavy brown waxed paper.  It was several sticks of dynamite - old Cap Bell had them hidden up in the floor joists.  (Ken)

Carroll Culver (owner of Pt. Lawrence Lodge) with 52lb salmon. Carroll was actually not much of a fisherman, and of course was too busy during the salmon season to fish himself, but he was not above a little self promotion.  (Ken)
photos.notes: Presumably the prize-winnign 52lb fish from image No. 0047.

photos.description: A summer storm destroys the floats at Pt. Lawrence Lodge.  Carroll watching helplessly as a freak July windstorm struck, severely damaging the largest float and several of the smaller ones. He was able to get the rental boats pulled up on the beach and all were saved. This was his worst nightmare, and he always worried about leaving the floats in past mid September for this reason, but late July was unheard of.  (Ken)

photos.people: Carroll Culver, Jean (Rothenhoefer) Culver, Ken Culver
photos.description: Carrol and Jean Culver, with baby Ken (born August 1941).
Photo of the Culver family farm.  One of my favorite images - what a difference color makes over black and white in this photo.

The ferry "City of Clinton" ran from Pt. Lawrence to Lummi Island for one year.  The little ferry was a single ender, with a turntable at the open end to turn vehicles around so they could drive off.  Bad weather and heavy tides were just too much for this venture which ended in failure.  Several of the old piling stubs are still visible at a minus tide on the beach.   (Source: Ken Culver)
